subject: Business
title: How Banks Make Money
description: A micro-lesson that makes How Banks Make Money usable.

hook.text: A bank pays you 0.5% on your savings. It lends that same money to someone else at 7%. The difference is profit.

buildup.text: The net interest margin â€” the spread between deposit rates and loan rates â€” is a bank's core revenue.

discovery.text: Banks also earn from fees: overdraft charges, ATM fees, credit card processing, and wealth management.

twist.text: Banks lend out far more money than they hold in deposits. This 'fractional reserve' system multiplies money supply.

climax.text: JPMorgan Chase earned $49.6 billion in 2023. Most came from lending your deposits at higher rates.

punchline.text: Your savings account isn't storing money. It's lending it to the bank cheaply.

quiz.question: What is a bank's 'net interest margin'?
options: The difference between what it pays depositors and what it charges borrowers
The bank's total revenue from fees
The interest a bank earns on government bonds
